sn6.8:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā divāvihāragato hoti paṭisallīno.
sn6.8:1.2.eng: Now at that time the Buddha had gone into retreat for the day’s meditation.

sn6.8:1.3.pli: Atha kho subrahmā ca paccekabrahmā suddhāvāso ca paccekabrahmā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā paccekaṃ dvārabāhaṃ nissāya aṭṭhaṃsu.
sn6.8:1.3.eng: Then the independent divinities Subrahmā and Suddhāvāsa went to the Buddha and stationed themselves one by each door-post.

sn6.8:1.4.pli: Atha kho suddhāvāso paccekabrahmā katamodakatissakaṃ bhikkhuṃ ārabbha bhagavato santike imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
sn6.8:1.4.eng: Then Suddhāvāsa spoke this verse about the mendicant Katamorakatissaka in the Buddha’s presence:

sn6.8:2.3.eng: I think anyone who’d do such a thing

sn6.8:2.4.eng: is an ignoramus, shrouded in darkness.”
sn6.8:2.4.comm: Akissava is a unique term, glossed as “lacking wisdom”. I take it as a + ki + (s)sava(na), “one who does not listen to anyone”.

sn6.9:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena kokāliko bhikkhu ābādhiko hoti dukkhito bāḷhagilāno.
sn6.9:1.2.eng: Now at that time the mendicant Kokālika was sick, suffering, gravely ill.
sn6.9:1.2.comm: His illness was caused by slandering Sāriputta and Moggallāna (SN 6.10, AN 10.89, Snp 3.10:3.3).| AN 10.89 combines this Sutta and the next.

sn6.9:1.3.pli: Atha kho turū paccekabrahmā abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇo kevalakappaṃ jetavanaṃ obhāsetvā yena kokāliko bhikkhu tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā vehāsaṃ ṭhito kokālikaṃ bhikkhuṃ etadavoca:
sn6.9:1.3.eng: Then, late at night, the glorious independent divinity Tudu, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, went up to the mendicant Kokālika, and standing in the air he said to him,

sn6.9:1.4.eng: “Kokālika, have confidence in Sāriputta and Moggallāna,

sn6.9:1.8.pli: “Nanu tvaṃ, āvuso, bhagavatā anāgāmī byākato, atha kiñcarahi idhāgato?
sn6.9:1.8.eng: “Didn’t the Buddha declare you a non-returner? So what then are you doing back here?

sn6.9:1.9.eng: See how far you have strayed!”

sn6.9:2.2.eng: with an axe in his mouth.

sn6.9:2.3.eng: A fool cuts themselves with it

sn6.9:3.1.eng: When you praise someone worthy of criticism,

sn6.9:3.2.eng: or criticize someone worthy of praise,

sn6.9:3.3.eng: you choose a losing hand with your own mouth:
sn6.9:3.3.comm: The ancient Indian game of dice involved casting vibhītaka seeds (also known as “bedda nuts”, from Terminalia bellirica) in a hollow, from which the players would take a handful. A number divisible by four was “perfect” (kaṭa), so the fifth seed meant a “losing” hand (kali; cf. apaṇṇaka in MN 60 and notes).

sn6.9:3.4.eng: you’ll never find happiness that way.

sn6.9:4.1.eng: A losing hand at dice is a trivial thing,

sn6.9:4.2.eng: if all you lose is your money

sn6.9:4.3.eng: and all you own, even yourself.

sn6.9:4.5.eng: is to hate the holy ones.

sn6.9:5.1.eng: For a hundred thousand times a hundred million,
sn6.9:5.1.comm: The interpretation and calculation of these lines is explained at Snp 3.10:12.2.

sn6.9:5.2.eng: times five hundred and thirty-six times <j>a thousand times ten million years

sn6.9:5.3.eng: a slanderer of noble ones goes to hell,

sn6.9:5.4.eng: having aimed bad words and thoughts at them.”

sn7.1:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
sn7.1:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

sn7.1:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññatarassa bhāradvājagottassa brāhmaṇassa dhanañjānī nāma brāhmaṇī abhippasannā hoti buddhe ca dhamme ca saṅghe ca.
sn7.1:1.3.eng: Now at that time the wife of a certain brahmin of the Bhāradvāja clan, a brahmin lady named Dhanañjānī, was devoted to the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha.
sn7.1:1.3.comm: Bhāradvāja features as the default Brahmanical clan in the Suttas, especially as antagonists who nonetheless are liable for conversion. The clan founder Bharadvāja Bārhaspatya, who is occasionally mentioned as a deity (DN 32:10.3), authored Maṇḍala 6 of the Rig Veda (DN 13:13.1). It would seem their star had dimmed, for they are listed as a low family (Bu Pc 2:2.1.18). | A devotee named Dhanañjānī appears in MN 100. She is perhaps the same person, although the setting and most of the narrative details are different. | The two names have the same sense: bhāradvāja is the “swift plunderer of booty”, while dhanañjānī is the “winner of wealth”, an epithet of Indra (and the name of a tariff-skimming brahmin at MN 97:2.13). These recall a much earlier age, when a raider on horseback or chariot would descend on villages and make off with the booty. Compare Vedic vājambhara (the swift “prize-winning” horse), and see O.H. De A. Wijesekera, Buddhist and Vedic Studies, p. 249.

sn7.1:1.4.pli: Atha kho dhanañjānī brāhmaṇī bhāradvājagottassa brāhmaṇassa bhattaṃ upasaṃharantī upakkhalitvā tikkhattuṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
sn7.1:1.4.eng: Once, while she was bringing her husband his meal, she tripped and expressed this heartfelt sentiment three times:

sn7.1:2.1.eng: “Homage to him, the blessed one, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha!
sn7.1:2.1.comm: This now-ubiquitous phrase is spoken only nine times in the Suttas: seven times by brahmins, and once each by Indra and Pasenadi. | The pronoun tassa (“to him”) is sometimes rendered with the impersonal “that” or “the”. But similar phrases take the personal pronoun (eg. “homage to you” at Snp 3.6:44.2, SN 2.9:2.1, “homage to them” at SN 2.25:6.4).

sn7.1:3.1.eng: Homage to him, the blessed one, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha!

sn7.1:4.1.eng: Homage to him, the blessed one, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha!”

sn7.1:5.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhāradvājagotto brāhmaṇo dhanañjāniṃ brāhmaṇiṃ etadavoca:
sn7.1:5.1.eng: When she said this, the brahmin said to Dhanañjānī:

sn7.1:5.2.pli: “evamevaṃ panāyaṃ vasalī yasmiṃ vā tasmiṃ vā tassa muṇḍakassa samaṇassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati.
sn7.1:5.2.eng: “That’d be right. For the slightest thing this lowlife woman spouts out praise for that bald ascetic.
sn7.1:5.2.comm: The term “lowlife” (vasala,  literally “little bullock”) is used of a degenerate gambler (Rig Veda 10.34.11). It is a word for one who violates dharma (justice, duty, goodness) through one’s actions, rather than being a description of birth (Manu 8.16).

sn7.1:5.3.pli: Idāni tyāhaṃ, vasali, tassa satthuno vādaṃ āropessāmī”ti.
sn7.1:5.3.eng: Right now, lowlife woman, I’m going to refute your teacher’s doctrine!”

sn7.1:5.4.pli: “Na khvāhaṃ taṃ, brāhmaṇa, passāmi sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya, yo tassa bhagavato vādaṃ āropeyya arahato sammāsambuddhassa.
sn7.1:5.4.eng: “Brahmin, I don’t see anyone in this world—with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—who can refute the doctrine of the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.

sn7.1:5.5.pli: Api ca tvaṃ, brāhmaṇa, gaccha, gantvā vijānissasī”ti.
sn7.1:5.5.eng: But anyway, you should go. When you’ve gone you’ll understand.”

sn7.1:6.1.pli: Atha kho bhāradvājagotto brāhmaṇo kupito anattamano yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
sn7.1:6.1.eng: Then the brahmin of the Bhāradvāja clan, angry and upset, went to the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him.

sn7.1:6.2.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
sn7.1:6.2.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side,

sn7.1:6.3.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho bhāradvājagotto brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn7.1:6.3.eng: and addressed the Buddha in verse:

sn7.1:7.1.eng: “When what is slain do you sleep at ease?
sn7.1:7.1.comm: Read jhatvā in line with SN 1.71. This question is asked by the famously violent Indra under the names Māgha (SN 2.3) and Sakka (SN 11.21).

sn7.1:7.2.eng: When what is slain is there no sorrow?

sn7.1:8.1.eng: “When anger’s slain you sleep at ease.

sn7.1:8.2.eng: When anger’s slain there is no sorrow.

sn7.1:8.3.eng: O brahmin, anger has a poisonous root

sn7.1:8.5.eng: The noble ones praise its killing,

sn7.1:8.6.eng: for when it’s slain there is no sorrow.”

sn7.1:9.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhāradvājagotto brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn7.1:9.1.eng: When he said this, the brahmin said to the Buddha,

sn7.1:9.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, bho gotama, nikkujjitaṃ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṃ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṃ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṃ dhāreyya: ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti; evamevaṃ bhotā gotamena anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
sn7.1:9.3.eng: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, worthy Gotama has made the teaching clear in many ways.
sn7.1:9.3.comm: The Buddha answered the question inside the brahmin’s question, hence his quick conversion.

sn7.1:9.4.pli: Esāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavantaṃ gotamaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
sn7.1:9.4.eng: I go for refuge to the worthy Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.

sn7.1:9.5.pli: Labheyyāhaṃ bhoto gotamassa santike pabbajjaṃ, labheyyaṃ upasampadan”ti.
sn7.1:9.5.eng: May I receive the going forth, the ordination in the worthy Gotama’s presence?”

sn7.1:10.1.pli: Alattha kho bhāradvājagotto brāhmaṇo bhagavato santike pabbajjaṃ, alattha upasampadaṃ.
sn7.1:10.1.eng: And the brahmin received the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence.

sn7.1:10.2.pli: Acirūpasampanno kho panāyasmā bhāradvājo eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto nacirasseva—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti tadanuttaraṃ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihāsi.
sn7.1:10.2.eng: Not long after his ordination, Venerable Bhāradvāja, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

sn7.1:10.3.pli: “Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā”ti abbhaññāsi.
sn7.1:10.3.eng: He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is nothing further for this place.”

sn7.1:10.4.pli: Aññataro ca panāyasmā bhāradvājo arahataṃ ahosīti.
sn7.1:10.4.eng: And Venerable Bhāradvāja became one of the perfected.

sn7.10:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kosalesu viharati aññatarasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe.
sn7.10:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Kosalans in a certain forest grove.
sn7.10:1.1.comm: Contrast this vivid description of the woes of the rural life with the satisfaction of the wealthy rancher at Snp 1.2.

sn7.10:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññatarassa bhāradvājagottassa brāhmaṇassa catuddasa balībaddā naṭṭhā honti.
sn7.10:1.2.eng: Now at that time one of the brahmins of the Bhāradvāja clan had lost fourteen oxen.

sn7.10:1.3.pli: Atha kho bhāradvājagotto brāhmaṇo te balībadde gavesanto yena so vanasaṇḍo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā addasa bhagavantaṃ tasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe nisinnaṃ pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāya parimukhaṃ satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvā.
sn7.10:1.3.eng: While looking for them he went to that forest grove, where he saw the Buddha sitting down cross-legged, his body set straight, and mindfulness established in his presence.

sn7.10:1.4.pli: Disvāna yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavato santike imā gāthāyo abhāsi:
sn7.10:1.4.eng: He went up to the Buddha, and recited these verses in the Buddha’s presence:

sn7.10:2.3.eng: missing for the past six days:

sn7.10:2.4.eng: that’s why this ascetic is happy.

sn7.10:3.3.eng: with just one or two leaves:

sn7.10:3.4.eng: that’s why this ascetic is happy.

sn7.10:4.4.eng: that’s why this ascetic is happy.

sn7.10:5.2.comm: For santhāra as “mat” or “carpet” (rather than “blanket”) see SN 35.243:2.1, AN 6.16:2.5, AN 3.35:2.1, AN 3.126:3.7, etc.

sn7.10:5.4.eng: that’s why this ascetic is happy.

sn7.10:6.3.eng: with one or two children each:
sn7.10:6.3.comm: All of whom would have been dependent on their father.

sn7.10:6.4.eng: that’s why this ascetic is happy.

sn7.10:7.2.eng: a wife with sallow, blotchy skin

sn7.10:7.3.eng: to wake him with a kick:

sn7.10:7.4.eng: that’s why this ascetic is happy.

sn7.10:8.4.eng: that’s why this ascetic is happy.”

sn7.10:9.1.comm: The Buddha appropriates and transforms the brahmin’s accusations, an early example of reclaiming language to see the “glass half full”.

sn7.10:9.3.eng: missing for the past six days:

sn7.10:10.1.eng: You’re right, brahmin, I don’t have

sn7.10:10.3.eng: with just one or two leaves:

sn7.10:11.1.eng: You’re right, brahmin, I don’t have

sn7.10:12.1.eng: You’re right, brahmin, I don’t have

sn7.10:13.1.eng: You’re right, brahmin, I don’t have

sn7.10:13.3.eng: with one or two children each:

sn7.10:14.1.eng: You’re right, brahmin, I don’t have

sn7.10:14.2.eng: a wife with blotchy, pockmarked skin

sn7.10:14.3.eng: to wake me up with a kick:

sn7.10:15.1.eng: You’re right, brahmin, I don’t have

sn7.10:16.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhāradvājagotto brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn7.10:16.1.eng: When he had spoken, the brahmin said to the Buddha,

sn7.10:16.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, bho gotama, nikkujjitaṃ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṃ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṃ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṃ dhāreyya: ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti; evameva bhotā gotamena anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
sn7.10:16.3.eng: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, worthy Gotama has made the teaching clear in many ways.

sn7.10:16.4.pli: Esāhaṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
sn7.10:16.4.eng: I go for refuge to the worthy Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.

sn7.10:16.5.pli: Labheyyāhaṃ bhoto gotamassa santike pabbajjaṃ, labheyyaṃ upasampadan”ti.
sn7.10:16.5.eng: May I receive the going forth, the ordination in the worthy Gotama’s presence?”

sn7.10:17.1.pli: Alattha kho bhāradvājagotto brāhmaṇo bhagavato santike pabbajjaṃ, alattha upasampadaṃ.
sn7.10:17.1.eng: And the brahmin received the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence.

sn7.10:17.2.pli: Acirūpasampanno panāyasmā bhāradvājo eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto nacirasseva—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihāsi.
sn7.10:17.2.eng: Not long after his ordination, Venerable Bhāradvāja, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

sn7.10:17.3.pli: “Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā”ti abbhaññāsi.
sn7.10:17.3.eng: He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is nothing further for this place.”

sn7.10:17.4.pli: Aññataro ca panāyasmā bhāradvājo arahataṃ ahosīti.
sn7.10:17.4.eng: And Venerable Bhāradvāja became one of the perfected.

sn7.11:1.1.comm: This discourse recurs at Snp 1.4 with a longer narrative. Vedic hymns include invocations to the “Lord of the Field” to bless the plowing and the crops (Rig Veda 4.57.4), but it is unorthodox to see a brahmin farmer.

sn7.11:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā magadhesu viharati dakkhiṇāgirismiṃ ekanāḷāyaṃ brāhmaṇagāme.
sn7.11:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Magadhans in the Southern Hills near the brahmin village of Ekanāḷa.
sn7.11:1.2.comm: The Southern Hills (dakkhiṇāgiri, “Deccan”) is the Vindhya Range that lies on the southern border of Magadha, leading southwest to Avanti. The Buddha and his disciples visited there so rarely that people complained (Kd 1:53.1.3). | Ekanāḷa (“one-stalk”) appears only here.

sn7.11:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena kasibhāradvājassa brāhmaṇassa pañcamattāni naṅgalasatāni payuttāni honti vappakāle.
sn7.11:1.3.eng: Now at that time the brahmin Bhāradvāja the Farmer had harnessed around five hundred plows, it being the season for sowing.

sn7.11:1.4.pli: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena kasibhāradvājassa brāhmaṇassa kammanto tenupasaṅkami.
sn7.11:1.4.eng: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to where Bhāradvāja the Farmer was working.

sn7.11:2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena kasibhāradvājassa brāhmaṇassa parivesanā vattati.
sn7.11:2.1.eng: Now at that time Bhāradvāja the Farmer was distributing food.
sn7.11:2.1.comm: Atharvaveda 6.142.3 says that the “givers” of the grain shall be inexhaustible, perhaps suggesting a food distribution practice.

sn7.11:2.2.pli: Atha kho bhagavā yena parivesanā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi.
sn7.11:2.2.eng: Then the Buddha went to where the distribution was taking place and stood to one side.

sn7.11:2.3.pli: Addasā kho kasibhāradvājo brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ piṇḍāya ṭhitaṃ.
sn7.11:2.3.eng: Bhāradvāja the Farmer saw him standing for alms

sn7.11:2.5.pli: “ahaṃ kho, samaṇa, kasāmi ca vapāmi ca, kasitvā ca vapitvā ca bhuñjāmi.
sn7.11:2.5.eng: “I plough and sow, ascetic, and then I eat.

sn7.11:2.6.pli: Tvampi, samaṇa, kasassu ca vapassu ca, kasitvā ca vapitvā ca bhuñjassū”ti.
sn7.11:2.6.eng: You too should plough and sow, then you may eat.”

sn7.11:2.7.pli: “Ahampi kho, brāhmaṇa, kasāmi ca vapāmi ca, kasitvā ca vapitvā ca bhuñjāmī”ti.
sn7.11:2.7.eng: “I too plough and sow, brahmin, and then I eat.”

sn7.11:2.8.pli: “Na kho mayaṃ passāma bhoto gotamassa yugaṃ vā naṅgalaṃ vā phālaṃ vā pācanaṃ vā balībadde vā, atha ca pana bhavaṃ gotamo evamāha:
sn7.11:2.8.eng: “I don’t see the worthy Gotama with a yoke or plow or plowshare or goad or oxen, yet he says:

sn7.11:2.9.pli: ‘ahampi kho, brāhmaṇa, kasāmi ca vapāmi ca, kasitvā ca vapitvā ca bhuñjāmī’”ti.
sn7.11:2.9.eng: ‘I too plough and sow, brahmin, and then I eat.’”

sn7.11:2.10.pli: Atha kho kasibhāradvājo brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn7.11:2.10.eng: Then Bhāradvāja the Farmer addressed the Buddha in verse:

sn7.11:3.2.eng: but I don’t see you farming.

sn7.11:3.3.eng: Tell me how you’re a farmer when asked:

sn7.11:3.4.eng: how am I to recognize your farming?”

sn7.11:4.1.eng: “Faith is my seed, fervor my rain,
sn7.11:4.1.comm: Vedic texts are full of this sort of correspondence, but I cannot find a close match to these. Perhaps this is to be expected, as the farmer is learning something new.

sn7.11:4.2.eng: and wisdom is my yoke and plough.

sn7.11:4.3.eng: Conscience is my pole, mind my strap,

sn7.11:5.2.eng: I restrict my intake of food.

sn7.11:5.3.eng: I use truth as my scythe,

sn7.11:6.1.eng: Energy is my beast of burden,

sn7.11:6.2.eng: transporting me to sanctuary from the yoke.
sn7.11:6.2.comm: Yogakkhema (“sanctuary from the yoke”) is a metaphor for Nibbana that draws from the literal sense of khema as an oasis or sanctuary for men and beasts. After a hard day’s journey, a caravan would stop to rest, “unyoke” the draft animals, lay down the burden, and refresh themselves in the cool waters.

sn7.11:6.4.eng: to where there is no sorrow.

sn7.11:7.1.eng: That’s how to do the farming

sn7.11:7.2.eng: that has freedom from death as its fruit.

sn7.11:8.2.eng: The worthy one is a farmer.

sn7.11:8.3.pli: Yañhi bhavaṃ gotamo amatapphalampi kasiṃ kasatī”ti.
sn7.11:8.3.eng: For the worthy Gotama does the farming that has freedom from death as its fruit.”

sn7.11:9.1.eng: “Food enchanted by a verse isn’t fit for me to eat.

sn7.11:9.2.eng: That’s not the principle of those who see, brahmin.

sn7.11:9.3.eng: The Buddhas cast aside things enchanted with verses.

sn7.11:9.4.eng: Since there is such a principle, brahmin, <j>that’s how they live.

sn7.11:10.1.eng: Serve with other food and drink

sn7.11:10.2.eng: the consummate one, the great seer,

sn7.11:10.3.eng: with defilements ended and remorse stilled.

sn7.11:10.4.eng: For he is the field for the seeker of merit.”

sn7.11:11.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, kasibhāradvājo brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn7.11:11.1.eng: When he had spoken, the brahmin Bhāradvāja the Farmer said to the Buddha,

sn7.11:11.3.eng: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

sn7.12:1.2.pli: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena udayassa brāhmaṇassa nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkami.
sn7.12:1.2.eng: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to the home of the brahmin Udaya.

sn7.12:1.3.pli: Atha kho udayo brāhmaṇo bhagavato pattaṃ odanena pūresi.
sn7.12:1.3.eng: Then Udaya filled the Buddha’s bowl with rice.

sn7.12:1.4.pli: Dutiyampi kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena udayassa brāhmaṇassa nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkami …pe…
sn7.12:1.4.eng: The next day … Udaya again filled the Buddha’s bowl with rice.

sn7.12:1.5.pli: tatiyampi kho udayo brāhmaṇo bhagavato pattaṃ odanena pūretvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn7.12:1.5.eng: But when he had filled the Buddha’s bowl on the third day, he said to the Buddha,

sn7.12:1.6.eng: “This ascetic Gotama is such a drag! He keeps coming back again and again!”
sn7.12:1.6.comm: Pakaṭṭhaka (“drag”) is unique. Commentary glosses “greedy for tastes” (rasagiddha). The basic sense is one who farms by drawing a plough, and the intensive prefix pa conveying someone who does that repeatedly, becoming annoying by drawing out or extracting.

sn7.12:2.1.eng: “Again and again, they sow the seed;

sn7.12:2.2.eng: again and again, the king of the heavens sends rain;
sn7.12:2.2.comm: The “king of the heavens” (devarājā) is Indra, god of the rain and thunder. This clarifies the common Pali idiom devo vassati, literally “the god rains”; the god is in fact Indra. In Pali this use of deva straddles the naturalistic and the religious. Often it is just an idiom expressing rainfall, while in other cases, as here, it has a religious connotation. For this reason I use “the heavens” for deva in such cases. It is a Vedic idiom (eg. Rig Veda 5.84.3 divo varṣanti;  9.108.10 vṛṣṭiṃ divaḥ pavasva; Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 4.3.1.16 divo varṣati).

sn7.12:2.3.eng: again and again, farmers plough the field;

sn7.12:2.4.eng: again and again, grain is produced for the nation.

sn7.12:3.1.eng: Again and again, the beggars beg;

sn7.12:3.2.eng: again and again, the donors give.

sn7.12:3.3.eng: Again and again, when the donors have given,

sn7.12:3.4.eng: again and again, they take their place in heaven.

sn7.12:4.1.eng: Again and again, dairy farmers milk;

sn7.12:4.2.eng: again and again, a calf cleaves to its mother;

sn7.12:4.3.eng: again and again, oppressing and intimidating,
sn7.12:4.3.comm: These verbs occur together in a list of crimes (SN 24.6:1.3).

sn7.12:4.4.eng: that dullard returns to the womb again and again.

sn7.12:5.1.eng: Again and again, you’re reborn and die;

sn7.12:5.2.eng: again and again, you get carried to a charnel ground.

sn7.12:5.3.eng: But when they’ve gained the path <j>for no further rebirth,

sn7.12:5.4.eng: one of vast wisdom is not reborn again and again.”

sn7.12:6.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, udayo brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn7.12:6.1.eng: When he had spoken, the brahmin Udaya said to the Buddha,

sn7.12:6.3.pli: upāsakaṃ maṃ bhavaṃ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gatan”ti.
sn7.12:6.3.eng: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
